Fun fact: An F-16 can pull 9 G's, F15's about 14 G's, with the right technique you might survive, but the plane might not. You don't do this for fun, actually.

Well, you do not "feel" any acceleration when you are falling, you feel it, when you are sitting or standing on the ground. So yes, a falling object accelerates with 1 g, but it does not "experience" or "feel" it, so the example does not make much sense for showing what you experience for certain accelerations.

1:49 I think this comparison is not really representative, since fighter pilot withstand those "low" G Forces for several seconds in very tight turns. The spider experiences the 130G for fractions of a second. Human testing showed that a person can endure 20-40G for little more than a second (1300ms) and not black out. If the time of de/acceleration is further decreased much higher Gs can be expected.

Really dumb comparison of G load. Prolonged Gs aren't the same as instantaneous G-loads. Humans have been known to survive dozens/hundreds of Gs in race car crashes for example. Not only that, but vertical G loads are completely different (in our biology) than horizontal G-loads. Not to mention our biology is completely different from SPIDERS. I would appreciate the video without the needless clickbait title.

One G shouldn’t be what’s felt when falling when you feel none, you meant standing I think.

simply AMAZING

The premise and title of this video are really dumb. Fighter pilots (humans) are much more massive and only cannot withstand 13g for prolonged periods of time because the brain cannot receive enough oxygenated blood. Most humans can experience/suffer many dozens of Gs and survive, provided the time the load was exerted is very short (like this spider's shot). Honestly, this spider's behaviour and biology are interesting enough without making an infantile and nonsensical comparison to humans.
